content: Before you start All hugo commands should be run in the root level
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 1: Install hugo && git For Mac user: brew install hugo brew install git
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 2: Create a new site hugo new site myblog cd myblog
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 3: Add a theme You can find Hugo themes Here In this case I use LoveIt theme as my example git init git submodule add https://github.com/dillonzq/LoveIt.git themes/LoveIt
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 4: Basic Configuration Copy config.toml content from example site to your config.toml You can make your own changes in config.toml file
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 5: Create your first post hugo new posts/my-first-post.md In .md file, set: draft: false Command above will generate a my-first-post.md file under the path: ./content/posts You should always use hugo new posts/file.md to create new files
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 6: Host the Website Locally hugo serve Go to http://localhost:1313
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

content: Step 7: Build the Website Run: hugo After you run the hugo command above, you will see content created under public folder in your blog folder
title: Build Your Hugo Blog Using GitHub and Netlify

Git Initialiaztion git add . git commit -m "first commit" git branch -M main git remote add origin https://github.com/your-github-username/your-repo-name.git git push -u origin main Whenever you make changes in your blog folder Run : hugo Above code will update corresponding changes to public folder Then run: $ git add . $ git commit -m "add blog post" $ git push You can use git status to check your changes $ git status
